item.title: Central Dogma
item.description: DNA is transcribed into RNA. RNA is translated into peptide chains, which fold into useful proteins. Proteins assist the cell in performing the functions of life, including replicating DNA.

item.title: Read It Now or Read It Never
item.description: Basically, get rid of your inboxes for links and stuff—you’re not going to really use them. When you come across something, you should either read it now or never read it.

item.title: Xenoblade Series
item.description: The Xeno- series (also sometimes called the Perfect Works saga) is a set of videogames that starts with Xenogears (1998). I’ve only played the Xenoblade Chronicles games and the relevant DLC.

item.title: Bistable Switch
item.description: ![[_media/bistable-switch.svg]] The bistable switch is a type of [[synbio/operon-model|operon]] that consists of two inhibitors. Because each one downregulates the activity of the other, this results in two stable phenotypes.

item.title: Hugo
item.description: Hugo is a static site generator written in go. [[_index|This wiki]] runs on Hugo. It’s a little more complicated to use than Jekyll, but it’s much faster and seems to work better for development.

item.title: Operon Model
item.description: Developed by Jacob and Monod, the operon describes methods of gene regulation and control. These genetic circuits help to produce varying phenotypes.

item.description: When approaching a difficult excerpt or passage in music, instinct tells us to practice it over and over again from start to finish.

item.title: Practice slow, then fast
item.description: Doing things fast is fun, but moving quickly without practice leads to mistakes. The best way to avoid this is to go slowly first.

item.description: Lateral domain shuffling Typical protein-based design strategies rely on breaking a protein down into individual domains. Modular domains can then be used to design new constructs and networks.

item.title: Naming Style Guide
item.description: Names are important! Especially when it comes to files and organization. Taking a little bit of time to establish a consistent syntax/style for naming makes it much easier to find things when you look for them later1.

item.title: Saccharomyces cerevisiae
item.description: Saccharomyces cerevisiae (baker’s yeast) is a well-characterized organism in biology. I’ve started working them in the summer of 2023, and I find them very friendly (especially compared to the fussiness of metazoan tissue culture).

item.title: Yeast Vectors
item.description: Yeast have three primary types of [[synbio/yeast-vectors|expression vectors]]: integrating plasmids, cen-ARS plasmids, and 2-micron plasmids. Genes of interest must be cloned into these for yeast experimentation.

item.title: The Archive Undying
item.description: Emma Mieko Candon’s The Archive Undying is a bizarre, semi-apocalyptic, scrap-punk sort of story. The narration swaps between first-, second-, and third-person, sometimes reaching all three within a single chapter.

item.title: The Bluest Eye
item.description: The Bluest Eye by Tony Morrison is a a book about racist distortions of beauty. That’s an oversimplification.

item.title: Parable of the Talents
item.description: If [[books/butler_parable-of-the-sower|Parable of the Sower]] was haunting, then Parable of the Talents was terrifying.

item.title: Moby Dick
item.description: Full disclosure: everything I knew about Moby Dick before reading this novel came from Bone by Jeff Smith. I did not know what I was in for.

item.title: The Joy Luck Club
item.description: The Joy Luck Club was a fantastic read. Amy Tan’s vivid stories about grandmothers hit home. Like most of the books I’m reading right now, I heard about it a few years ago in one of my English classes from another student.

item.title: A Prayer for the Crown-Shy
item.description: A Prayer for the Crown-Shy is a worthy sequal to A Psalm for the Wild-Built. This book, too, reads like a fairy tale, though this is more of a “stranger in a strange land” situation.

item.title: The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks
item.description: In The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks, Rebecca Skloot—alongside Deborah Lacks and the rest of the Lacks family—tells the story of Henrietta Lacks and the HeLa cell line that was made from her.

item.title: The Future Is Disabled
item.description: The Future is Disabled by Leah Lakshmi Piepzna-Samarasinha reads like a good kick in the teeth. Their writing feels like someone is talking to you.

item.title: Jellyfish Age Backwards
item.description: I picked up this book because I wanted to learn about jellyfish and some of the biochemistry behind ageing. What I got was a mix of pop science around ageing.

item.title: The Mimicking of Known Successes
item.description: Malka Older’s The Mimicking of Known Successes is a nice, if relatively straightforward, mystery novel. It’s also a romance. The setting is neat, but nothing about this book really stuck out to me.

item.title: How the Word Is Passed
item.description: How the Word Is Passed is a great introduction to the history of systemic racism. Clint Smith tells the story of racism through places, in a sort of museum-learning style.

item.title: Foundation
item.description: Isaac Asimov’s Foundation is a sci-fi novel that follows statistician Hari Seldon and his disciples as they work to mitigate a galactic disaster.

item.title: The Mythical Man-month
item.description: I would have gotten more out of this book if I were a software engineer or full-blown computer programmer. Much of the contents went over my head, since I’m not a member of that target audience.

item.title: We Could Have Been Friends, My Father and I
item.description: Raja Shehadeh’s We Could Have Been Friends, My Father and I is part-memoir, part-history, and part-biography. In it, Shehadeh chronicles his father’s long fight for Palestinian liberation.

item.title: Wild Massive
item.description: Wild Massive by Scotto Moore is like The Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy but the universe is inside a building and features amusement parks.

item.title: Stolen Focus
item.description: Stolen Focus sounds like a self-help book, but it isn’t. Johann Hari takes a systems-first approach to understanding distraction, rather than centering the individual.

item.title: The Rock Eaters
item.description: The Rock Eaters is an anthology by Brenda Peynado. The stories within range from magical realism to speculative fiction to science-fiction.

item.title: Killers of a Certain Age
item.description: If I had to describe this book in a single sentence it would be “It’s like John Wick but with middle-aged women.

item.title: Tidesong
item.description: Wendy Xu’s Tidesong is a graphic novel about a girl who goes to study magic with her great-aunt. The artwork is beautiful.

item.title: Invisible Man
item.description: This book. Oh boy this book. Ralph Ellison is a phenomenal writer. I loved reading Invisible Man. It’s a brilliant story, but to simply call it a novel is reductive.

item.title: Animal Farm
item.description: Animal Farm, by George Orwell, is a satirical novel about fascism and communism. Framed as a fairy tale about a group of animals that overthrow their farmer, Animal Farm chronicles the farm’s slow descent into tyranny as the pigs gain more and more power as the governing body.

item.title: The Emperor of All Maladies
item.description: The first of Siddharta Mukherjee’s three books (the others are The Gene and The Song of the Cell), The Emperor of All Maladies is a masterfully-written chronicle of cancer and oncology.

item.title: Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde
item.description: One of my friends reminded me that this book existed last week. I borrowed it out as an ebook this morning and read it on the bus.

item.title: Hooky
item.description: Hooky by Míriam Tur is a cutesy book about a pair of siblings trying to get through the year after accidentally missing the bus to their boarding school.

item.title: On Writing Well
item.description: In his book On Writing Well, William Zinsser outlines a set of best practices and techniques for writers of all stripes and skills.

item.title: Entangled Life
item.description: Mushrooms have been making the rounds on the internet and in pop culture. At the Renaissance Fair last year, I saw more than zero people dressed up as mushrooms.

item.title: The Butchering Art
item.description: The Butchering Art is another fantastic work of scientific and historical journalism, chronicling the transformation of Victorian medicine through the life of Joseph Lister—the surgeon who pioneered sterilization via carbolic acid.

item.title: Hood Feminism
item.description: Hood Feminism is a collection of essays about feminism, racism, poverty, and change. Each essay focuses on a different issue: hunger, racist beauty standards, the systemic exclusion of non-white needs from mainstream feminism, and other topics.

item.title: Song of Solomon
item.description: Toni Morrison is a fantastic author, and Song of Solomon is not an exception to that rule. Like in her other works, Morrison fills every sentence in Song of Solomon with nuance and symbolism.

item.title: The Gene
item.description: At first glance, The Gene book is hefty—and it’s certainly not a novel. It took me a couple months to finish this one.

item.title: The Song of the Cell
item.description: My parents gave me this book as a Christmas gift. I had been working in a lab with cells and all sorts of other things for about six months by then, and I was (and still am) convinced that research was the place to be.

item.title: Sapiens
item.description: Sapiens is not like your history textbooks. It’s a book about history, yes, and it covers the same span of time as a highschool or college world history class.

item.title: A Psalm for the Wild-Built
item.description:
I think I have a new favorite book.

Becky Chambers’s A Psalm for the Wild-Built is a beautiful book about a tea-brewing therapist in a post-cataclysm world going on a road trip with a robot. Chambers’s vivid prose brings to life a story about friendship, agency, and personal purpose.
